In situ prepared copper nanoparticles on modified KIT-5 as an efficient recyclable catalyst and its applications in click reactions in water Razieh Mirsafaei a Majid M. Heravi b ⁎ Shervin Ahmadi c Mohammad Hossein Moslemin a Tayebeh Hosseinnejad b a Department of Chemistry, Yazd Branch, Islamic Azad University, Yazd, Iran Department of Chemistry Yazd Branch Islamic Azad University Yazd Iran b Department of Chemistry, Alzahra University, Vanak, Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry Alzahra University Vanak Tehran Iran c Iran Polymer and Petrochemical Institute, Tehran, Iran Iran Polymer and Petrochemical Institute Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 9121329147; fax: +98 21 88041344. Graphical abstract A novel heterogeneous copper nano catalyst supported on modified silica mesopore KIT-5 was successfully prepared. The 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) on KIT-5 was coordinated with copper(I) and accurately characterized. In addition a comparative survey on the metal-ligand interactions in the syntheses of catalyst in two different solvents via density functional theory calculations was performed. A one-pot procedure for syntheses of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole derivatives via a three-component reaction between terminal alkynes, alkyl halides, and sodium azide, namely click reaction in the presences of 3mol% nanoparticles copper/APTES-KIT-5 (Cu/AK) as a catalyst was developed to give the products in good to excellent yields. This catalyst showed high catalytic activity in water as a “green” solvent. This reaction was performed under open air conditions and required no special reaction conditions and chromatographic separation for purification. Keywords Mesoporous silica KIT-5 Green solvent Cu-catalyzed azide/alkyne click reaction Copper heterogeneous Nanocatalys Density functional theory calculations 1 Introduction After important report so called ‘click chemistry’ by Kolb et al., an enormous number of paper has been published on development copper(I)-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) to synthesize 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles in excellent yields [1]. 1,2,3-Triazoles are important class of heterocyclic compounds with wide range of applications. Some of them are pharmaceutical agents, agrochemicals, and photographic materials [2]. One of the most general method for the syntheses of 1,2,3-triazole derivatives, is the well-known 1,3-dipolar Huisgen cycloaddition which is involving the Cu catalyzed cycloaddition reaction of azides with alkynes [3,4]. Recovery and reusability of the catalysts is very important in heterogeneous catalysis. In order to take advantage of reusability of copper species as catalyst, for ease of recovery, they have been immobilized onto various supports, such as amine-functionalized polymers [5], zeolites [6], aluminum oxyhydroxide fiber [7] and amine-functionalized silica [8]. Heterogeneous catalysis is of supreme importance in many areas of the chemical and energy consuming industries [9]. In heterogeneous catalysis, the quality and extent of the surface area of the catalyst is crucial. Silica based compounds such as SBA-16, SBA-1 and KIT-5 are the best choice as support surface due to their maximizing surface area [10,11]. They have large area and thus are effective in organic heterogeneous catalyzed reactions. Among them, KIT-5, which was discovered by Ryoo research group, is highly well-ordered nanocage type mesoporous with cubic Fm3m close packed symmetry, with high surface area, large pores, and a high specific pore volume [12]. Due to our interests in heterogeneous catalysis, applied in a variety of organic transformations [13–23], and recent successful attempts for the syntheses of 1,2,3-triazoles, via click reaction [24–36], in this paper we wish to report the preparation of copper nano catalyst on modified KIT-5 (CuI/AK) as a superior heterogeneous catalyst in the syntheses of 1,2,3-triazoles via click reaction. This heterogeneous catalyst system exhibited an excellent catalytic performance for 1,3-dipolar Huisgen cycloaddition reaction in the construction of the various 1,2,3-triazole derivatives. Moreover, Cu/AK can be recovered easily and being re-used several times in the aforementioned transformation, with no appreciable loss of activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All reagents were purchased from Aldrich and Merck with high-grade quality and used as received. The structural characteristics of the KIT-5 which was obtained, using three dimensional large cage type face centered cubic Fm3m mesoporous silica materials (KIT-5) nano cages were obtained according to the procedure described previously [12] using Pluronic F127 (EO106PO70EO106) as the template which briefly summarized in Table 1 . The samples were calcined at 550°C for 6h to remove the template prior to use. 2.2 Equipments X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the materials were recorded on a Bruker D8 advanced powder X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα (λ =1.54°A) as the radiation source in the 2θ; range of 2–60°.The FT-IR spectra of the samples were recorded in the range of 4000–400cm−1 on an FT-IR spectrometer (PerkinElmer) using KBr pellet technique. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) Lecia Cambridge S 360 was used to observe the morphology of the modified and unmodified mesoporous silicas. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS) Genesis, with an SUTW detector equipped with SEM equipment, was used to carry out the EDXS analysis in order to confirm the presence of silica. 2.3 Preparation of catalyst 2.3.1 Preparation of amine functionalized mesoporous KIT-5 A suspension of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (1.00g) and calcined KIT-5 (1.00g) in toluene (20ml) as a solvent was refluxed with continuous stirring under N2 atmosphere for 24h. Then, the resultant solid was filtered and washed with 1:1 mixture of acetone and chloroform in order to remove the un-reacted 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane, and subsequently dried under vacuum at 80°C. The un-reacted APTES was removed by Soxhlet extraction using dry dichloromethane for 20h and dried at 60°C. The sample was denoted as APTES/KIT-5 (shown Scheme 1 ). 2.3.2 Deposition of copper on APTES/KIT-5 (CuI/AK) using CuI as copper source CuI (200mg) was dissolved in 3ml of acetonitrile and stirred for 30min at room temperature. As a result a transparent pale yellow solution was obtained. To this mixture, 1.00g APTES/KIT-5 was added and magnetically stirred under reflux, and nitrogen atmosphere for 5h under nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was filtered and the obtained solid, the CuI/AK (4) was washed with acetonitrile and dried under vacuum at 60°C (Scheme 2 ). SEM and energy dispersive spectroscopy analysis of X-rays (EDAXS) technique were used to characterize the obtained catalyst. 2.4 Syntheses of 1,4-disubstituted triazoles: a typical procedure In a round-bottom flask, an appropriate α-haloketone (1mmol) or alkyl halide (1mmol) (5a–h), alkyne (1mmol) (6a–c), sodium azide (1.1mmol) were mixed 10ml water (Scheme 3 ). To this mixture, 0.03g of prepared CuI/AK as catalyst was added. This suspension was magnetically stirred under reflux conditions for appropriate time, as indicated in Table 2 . The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC (n-hexane: ethylacetate; 7:3). Upon the completion of the reaction, the resin was filtered and washed with hot ethanol. The recovered catalyst was washed with acetone, dried under reduced pressured at 70°C for 3h and stored for another consecutive reaction.The filtrate was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure to give the crude material, which in some cases (7e–h) was washed with 10ml of ether. Finally the solid residue was re-crystallized from EtOH/H2O (3:1 v/v) to afford the product. All obtained triazoles (7a–k) were known and their physical data were compared with those of authentic compounds and found to be identical [24–36]. 2.5 The spectral (IR, 1H NMR and 13C NMR) data for the selected compound is presented below [24–30] Table 2 Entry 1: 1-Phenyl-2-(4-phenyl-[1,2,3]triazol-1-yl) ethanone (7a). IR (KBr): υ =3099 (m), 1655 (s), 1216 (s) cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of the aminated KIT-5 Initially, KIT-5 (1) was successfully modified using, 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) group (2). To confirm the grafting of APTES into the surface of KIT-5, various kinds of analysis were contemplated and done. Fig. 1 presents the FT-IR spectrum of pure KIT-5 and APTES/KIT-5. Similar to mesoporous silica KIT-5 (a) and APTES/KIT-5 sample (b) shows the typical vibrations of asymmetric and symmetric stretching as well as the rocking of SiOSi, around 1070, 814, and 457cm−1. The band at around 950cm−1 is can be assigned SiOH vibration of the surface silanols, which is characteristic of mesoporous silica. The existence of APTES in the KIT-5/APTES is evidenced by the appearance of typical APTES vibration on the FTIR spectrum (b). The presence of NH bending vibration at 694cm−1 and NH2 symmetric bending vibration at 1582cm−1, which are not observed in neat KIT-5 IR spectrum, indicated the successful grafting of organic amine onto the surface. IR spectrum of NH2-(CH2)3-Si-KIT-5 showed the asymmetric vibration at 2936cm−1, characteristic for the CH2 groups of the propyl chain of the silylating agent. Thus, it is confirmed that APTES molecules exist on the surface of the KIT-5, concluding that APTES molecules were successfully incorporated with KIT-5. 3.2 Preparation and characterization of the catalysts CuI/AK The high surface area, special geometry, having a highly specific pore volume, make KIT-5 mesoporous in a way to make it an ideal support, being used extensively in catalyzed organic syntheses. Heravi et al. applied successfully the modified KIT-5 with polymer, as a support for the immobilization of palladium nanoparticles to make it an effective and powerful catalyst and used it in a Pd catalyzed reaction, such as the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction [37]. Armed with this back ground, we contemplated the amination of KIT-5 with 3-amino-triethoxysilane. Bearing, NH2 group, 3-aminotriethoxysilane is expected to act as a good coordinating agent. Remarkably, we found out, it is commercially available and less expensive than other silano amines, in the chemical market. Thus, we thought, it is worthwhile being tested for the modification of KIT-5 in order to prepare a new and an influential and cost-effective support. In the following, copper iodides were successfully immobilized on modified KIT-5 using found optimized conditions that involving, mmol ratio of amine to mmol of Cu of 2.4:1.0 [37], to afford the desired CuI/AK catalyst. Morphology and location of metallic species on the surface of the catalyst were analyzed by SEM microscope equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray analyzer (EDXS) and wide-angle XRD (WAXRD) pattern. Fig. 2 illustrates the WAXRD pattern of CuI/AK nanocatalyst (2θ =5–70°). The crystallite size of particles was evaluated using Bragg’s equation (nλ =2dsinθ), found to be approx. 35nm for CuI/AK catalyst (2θ =25.46° approx.). As it can be seen from this figure, all reflection peaks could be indexed to the pure cubic crystal phase of nano crystalline CuI. Sharp peaks of copper (2θ =25.4696, 29.5304, 42.2052, 49.9519, 52.3423 and 61.2088) are observed which indicate the crystalline nature of the product. No specific peaks due to any impurities were observed. This pattern is in good agreement with the reported pattern for copper iodide (Marshite, syn; code Ref. 60246). Additionally, this also confirmed the formation of nano CuI particles onto APTES/KIT-5. This was concluded from the observation of this fact that symmetry had been destroyed by the hybridization in the ordered mesoporous silica loading with guest matter. Consequently, we like to claim the preparation of a novel Cu/AK nanocatalyst, fruitfully. Referring to Scheme 2, in order to expand the scope of the syntheses of this new nanocatalyst, we decided to perform the syntheses in two different solvents such as DMF and acetonitrile. The loading of Cu on support has proceeded smoothly in both solvents and consequently Cu immobilized nano catalyst was provided. For coming to conclusion for choice of solvent, the size of the immobilized coppers on surfaces of the catalyst, was measured. The SEM image of the catalyst obtained in DMF was also recorded and compared with that of, the species, already synthesized in acetonitrile. As illustrated in Fig. 3 (a–f) and map Fig. 3g, the more efficient immobilization and smaller size of CuI on modified KIT-5 was clearly shown in SEM image taken from the sample obtained in acetonitrile. Due to insolubilities of the CuI/AK catalyst in all common organic solvents, for structural elucidation, we were limited to its SEM, EDAX and XRD analysis techniques. Fig. 3(a–f) shows the SEM images after immobilization copper on modified KIT-5 in two aforementioned solvents. Clear and vivid changes in the morphologies of the catalyst after introduction of metals in two different solvents were observed. The scanning electron micrographs of the Cu/AK catalyst (Fig. 3d–f) clearly show the CuI nanoparticles were homogeneously immobilized on modified surface. The map of catalyst approved this homogenous dispersity. Cu nanoparticle (green point) uniformly disperses on silica mesopores (red point). But in DMF solvent agglomeration take place. Considering the SEM images of Cu/AK, the average size of copper NPs was estimated to be 12–40nm. Energy dispersive spectroscopy analysis of X-rays (EDAX) data for this catalyst is given in Fig. 4 . The EDX data also reveals the attachment of copper metal on the surface of the modified KIT-5 matrix, vividly. Comparisons of EDX analysis of Cu/AK confirms the loading of copper to the modified support, which is a good evidence for the formation of metal complexes with the anchored ligand (Fig. 4). 3.3 Computational Recently, we have performed a computational study to find a quantitative description for metal-ligand interactions in the modified poly (styrene-co-maleic anhydride) palladium nanocatalyst [37]. Armed with this experience, we concentrated on a comparative assessment of metal-ligand interactions in copper-aminated KIT-5 nanocatalyst 4 (CuI/AK) in the presence of two different solvents: acetonitrile and dimethylformamide (DMF) by performing density functional theory (DFT) calculations [38] to investigate the solvent effect on experimental affordance of CuI/AK complexation reaction. In this respect, we have employed an appropriate model for modified KIT-5 ligand (APTES/KIT-5) 3 and CuI/AK complex 4 (as was illustrated in Scheme 4 ). It is worthwhile to mention that although our proposed model for modified KIT-5 ligand and its complex with CuI includes only the initial step of complexation but it can be considered as an effective model for comparative investigation of solvent effect. Moreover, as we have shown in our previous work [37], this size of structural model for a polymer or silica supported catalyst has a reliable comprise between accuracy and time saving efficiency of computational procedure. DFT computations were performed at M06/6-31G* level of theory to determine the optimized structure of compounds 3 and 4 [39]. It is worthy to mention that the harmonic frequency analysis was used to confirm that the found structures correspond to minima. In Fig. 5 we have demonstrated energy minimized structure of KIT-5 ligand (APTES/KIT-5) and CuI/AK complex calculated at M06/6-31G* level of theory. In the case of copper and iodine atoms, LANL2DZ effective core potentials (ECPs) were used together with the accompanying basis sets to describe the valence electron density [40,41]. Moreover, the effects of solvent on the energetic features of complexation have been examined on the basis of a continuum representation of the solvent surrounding the substances via polarized continuum model (PCM) [42]. It is important to mention that the basis set superposition error (BSSE) has been included in calculation of complexation energies via the standard counterpoise procedure [43]. All DFT computations have been performed using GAMESS suite of programs [44]. In Table 3 , we have presented comparatively M06/6-31G* calculated electronic energies changes in the complexation process (as was shown in Scheme 4) and also the calculated bond orders of CuN chemical bonds in two different solution phases. The results, reported in Table 3 demonstrate that the complexation process is more favorable in acetonitrile than DMF from the electronic energy point of view. Furthermore, the CuN bond orders in CuI-APTES/KIT-5 complex 4 has larger calculated values in acetonitrile solution in comparison with those in DMF which confirms the practical preference of acetonitrile as solvent rather than DMF. 3.4 Preparation and characterization of 1,4-disubstituted triazoles In order to investigate the effect of solvent for this click reaction, different solvents, such as acetonitrile, dichloromethane, ethanol, EtOH:H2O and water were examined (Table 4 ). To find the optimal reaction conditions, the reaction of 2-bromoacetophenone (1mmol), sodium azide (1.1mmol) and phenyl acetylene (1mmol) as a terminal alkyne was selected as a model reaction and studied under a variety of conditions, initially performed in different solvents. As shown in Table 4, the most appropriate solvents for the reaction have been found EtOH/H2O and H2O in entries 4 and 5, respectively. Although the reaction can be performed in the both aforementioned conditions (EtOH/H2O and water), water was reasonably was chosen, dictated by green chemistry disciplines and our previous experiences [20,31]. Optimization of the amount of the catalyst was also studied. The desired reaction was performed in water and different amounts of the loaded catalyst (Table 5 ). As shown in Table 5, entry 3, the best result was achieved by conducting the reaction of phenyl bromide, phenylacetylene and sodium azide (with 1:1:1.1mol ratios) in the presence of 0.03g of CuI/AK in refluxing water as a green solvent. Using this concluded optimized conditions, in order to establish the methodology, a series of 1,2,3-triazoles were successfully synthesized (Table 2). Structural assignments of triazoles were made by comparison of their physical data with, those of authentic samples, reported previously. Reusability of the catalyst was also examined and found promising. A model reaction was conducted 6 times with recycled catalysts under similar conditions and only non-appreciable loss of weight was observed in the obtained desired compound. (Fig. 6 ). After each cycle, the catalyst was filtered off, washed with water (15mL) and dried in oven at 60°C and reused further in the next click reaction without any further modification. In addition only small difference between the copper content of the fresh catalyst and the reused catalyst was observed indicating the low leaching amount of CuI catalyst into the reaction mixture. To show the advantages of CuI/AK as a heterogeneous nanocatalyst in this reaction, our results and reaction conditions for the syntheses of 1-phenyl-2-(4-phenyl-[1,2,3]triazol-1-yl) ethanone (7a) were compared with the homogeneous catalysis of this reaction, previously reported (Table 6 ). The results show that our catalyst is quite comparable with that of used homogeneous catalyst regarding the yields and reaction times. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we prepared a new aminated silica supported CuNPs catalyst via in situ NPs preparation. This novel organic–inorganic hybrid material, Cu nanoparticles Cu/AK, was achieved via a facile and efficient method. The catalytic activity of this novel nanocatalyst was examined and found excellent in the syntheses of biologically important 1,4-disubstituted-1H-1,2,3-triazoles via Huisgen 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction, so called click reaction, between terminal alkynes, α-halo ketones or alkyl halide and NaN3 in green media. Most importantly, water has been chosen and worked well, as a green solvent for this reaction. This new heterogeneous catalyst shows many advantages; high catalytic activity under mild reaction conditions; easy separation after reaction via filtration and reusability for several times without any appreciable loss in the yield of the reactions. Thus, we believe our catalyst is worthwhile to be applied to other Cu-catalyzed organic reactions and also our modified mesopores support as an attractive, powerful and cost-effective support should stir up the interest of synthetic organic chemists who are focused on catalyzed organic syntheses. coredata.dc:description: A novel heterogeneous copper nano catalyst supported on modified silica mesopore KIT-5 was successfully prepared. The 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) on KIT-5 was coordinated with copper(I) and accurately characterized. In addition a comparative survey on the metal-ligand interactions in the syntheses of catalyst in two different solvents via density functional theory calculations was performed. A one-pot procedure for syntheses of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole derivatives via a three-component reaction between terminal alkynes, alkyl halides, and sodium azide, namely click reaction in the presences of 3mol% nanoparticles copper/APTES-KIT-5 (Cu/AK) as a catalyst was developed to give the products in good to excellent yields. This catalyst showed high catalytic activity in water as a “green” solvent. This reaction was performed under open air conditions and required no special reaction conditions and chromatographic separation for purification.
coredata.dc:title: In situ prepared copper nanoparticles on modified KIT-5 as an efficient recyclable catalyst and its applications in click reactions in water
